data.title: Diplomatic Number Plates used within the UK
data.meta_description: Diplomatic Number Plates used within the UK, ever wanted to know what country or what type of staff is within the vehicle, CVB brings you the ultimate guide.
data.text:
Have you ever wondered what a diplomatic number plate is?

We have brought together all the information into one easy place, explaining how diplomatic number plates are formatted. We also show you which countries are associated with diplomatic plates used with the UK.

Since 1979, motor vehicles operated by foreign embassies, high commissions, consulates and international organisations have been issued unique vehicle registration marks.

To obtain permission to use a diplomatic number plate eligible officials are required to be accredited by the Foreign & Commonwealth Office (FCO) who liaise with Specialist Registrations at the Driver & Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) for issuance. Click this link to INF267 which explains the process.

There are a number of key factors with diplomatic number plates:

Format of diplomatic number plates

The format of all diplomatic number plates in the UK is identical in that you have three numbers then a space, then either a D or X ad then three more numbers.

Where you see a D in a diplomatic number plate this is used by vehicles used by actual diplomats, whereas the letter C signifies that the vehicle is used for non-diplomatic accredited personnel.

The first group of three numbers is used to identify the country or international organisation.

The second group of three numbers signifies to the type of user e.g. starting at 101 for diplomats, 400 for non-diplomatic staff of international organisations, and 700 upwards for consular or other non-diplomatic staff.

Country related to diplomatic number plates
